information:
The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled to take place on June 16, 2025, in Chicago. The James Beard Foundation has recently made efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity in its awards program. These changes include the introduction of new categories, such as Best New Bar, Outstanding Professional in Beverage Service, and Outstanding Professional in Cocktail Service, as well as a shift to a regional model for the Best Chef category.

Several women have been named as finalists for the 2025 James Beard Awards. Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA, is a finalist for the national award of Outstanding Chef. Other female finalists in regional categories include Sarah Thompson of Casa Playa in Las Vegas (Best Chef: Southwest), Amanda Shulman of Her Place Supper Club in Philadelphia (Best Chef: Mid-Atlantic), and Erin Miller of Urban Hearth in Cambridge (Best Chef: Northeast).

In the last ten award cycles for James Beard Outstanding Chef, women have won four times. Since 2020, the James Beard Foundation has implemented an equity initiative. Following this, the share of female winners in the regional Best Chef awards increased from approximately 30% before 2020 to around 55% in 2024. The winners of the Outstanding Chef award in 2023 (Rob Rubba) and 2024 (Michael Rafidi) were men.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — a man wins Outstanding Chef
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: One of the male Outstanding Chef finalists is selected (continuing the 2023–2024 pattern).
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Cassie Piuma of Sarma (or any other woman finalist in the national Outstanding Chef category, if listed) wins.
forecast.rationale:
- Timing: Winners are announced June 16, 2025, so resolution is imminent.
- Base rates: Over the last 10 award cycles, women won Outstanding Chef 4/10 times (~40%). However, the last two winners (2023 Rob Rubba, 2024 Michael Rafidi) were men, which nudges the near-term status quo toward No.
- Finalists mix: The research notes at least one woman finalist for Outstanding Chef (Cassie Piuma). It does not confirm multiple women in the national Outstanding Chef slate, while mentioning several women in regional categories (not relevant to this question). If there is only one woman among ~5 finalists, an equal-strength naive probability would be ~20%. If there are two women, ~40% naive.
- Institutional tilt: Since 2020, the Foundation’s equity initiative has increased female representation among regional winners (to ~55% in 2024). That likely modestly raises the odds for a woman at the national level relative to historical norms, but the last two national winners were men, suggesting no strong recent tilt in Outstanding Chef outcomes.
- Synthesis: Combine (a) a historical female-win base of ~40%, (b) likely fewer women than men in the national finalist pool (possibly one), and (c) modest upward adjustment for ongoing equity efforts and the strength/visibility of Cassie Piuma. This yields a probability notably above the single-seat naive 20% but below the 40% long-run base.
- Why not higher: We lack evidence of multiple women finalists in the national category or clear pre-ceremony sentiment that a woman is the frontrunner; recent winners have been men.
- Why not lower: The Foundation’s equity focus and at least one strong woman finalist keep the chance meaningfully above a pure 1-in-5 naive share.
- What would move me up: Confirmation that there are multiple women among the Outstanding Chef finalists; credible pre-award reporting or odds signaling a woman (e.g., Cassie Piuma) as the frontrunner.
- What would move me down: Confirmation that only one woman is a finalist and pre-award buzz strongly favors a specific male finalist; any reporting suggesting Piuma (or other women finalists) are long shots.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will a woman win the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef?

Question background:
[Here Are the 2025 James Beard Awards Restaurant, Chef, and Media Award Finalists](https://www.eater.com/24398769/2025-james-beard-awards-restaurant-chef-finalists)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if a woman wins the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef.




Your research assistant's report says:
The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled to take place on June 16, 2025, in Chicago. The James Beard Foundation has recently made efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity in its awards program. These changes include the introduction of new categories, such as Best New Bar, Outstanding Professional in Beverage Service, and Outstanding Professional in Cocktail Service, as well as a shift to a regional model for the Best Chef category.

Several women have been named as finalists for the 2025 James Beard Awards. Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA, is a finalist for the national award of Outstanding Chef. Other female finalists in regional categories include Sarah Thompson of Casa Playa in Las Vegas (Best Chef: Southwest), Amanda Shulman of Her Place Supper Club in Philadelphia (Best Chef: Mid-Atlantic), and Erin Miller of Urban Hearth in Cambridge (Best Chef: Northeast).

In the last ten award cycles for James Beard Outstanding Chef, women have won four times. Since 2020, the James Beard Foundation has implemented an equity initiative. Following this, the share of female winners in the regional Best Chef awards increased from approximately 30% before 2020 to around 55% in 2024. The winners of the Outstanding Chef award in 2023 (Rob Rubba) and 2024 (Michael Rafidi) were men.

Today is 2025-05-27.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
